importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The year when the sexual assault at Gettysburg College occurred, marking the beginning of a prolonged legal and emotional journey for the victim.
The year when Ian Cleary sent a Facebook message that said, 'So I raped you,' prompting the victim to renew her efforts to pursue legal action.

The year when Shannon Keeler shared her experience in an Associated Press story about prosecutors’ reluctance to pursue campus sexual assault cases, leading to renewed attention and eventual indictment.
The date when Ian Cleary was detained in Metz, France, on a vagrancy charge, which inadvertently led to his arrest and extradition to the U.S. for the sexual assault case.
The date when Ian Cleary was sentenced to two to four years in prison, marking the culmination of a 12-year legal process.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which the initial assault occurred, setting the timeline for the victim’s long-standing pursuit of justice.
The period during which the victim continued to advocate for justice, including public disclosure of her experience, which influenced prosecutors to act.
The period during which the case was resolved, including extradition, prosecution, and sentencing, highlighting the difficulty of tracking offenders over time.

keyTakeAways: The victim, Shannon Keeler, was sexually assaulted in 2013 at Gettysburg College and spent years pursuing legal action, with the case ultimately being prosecuted more than a decade later.
Ian Cleary, the perpetrator, was extradited from France in 2024 after being detained on a vagrancy charge, indicating the difficulty of tracking campus sexual offenders across jurisdictions.
The case underscores systemic failures in campus sexual assault prosecution, including the destruction of evidence and prosecutors’ reluctance to act, especially when time has passed.
Cleary’s guilty plea and expressed remorse, along with his history of mental illness, influenced the judge to impose a sentence below state guidelines.
The message sent by Cleary in 2019 — 'So I raped you' — was not an act of violence, but a symbolic gesture of atonement through a 12-step program, which re-traumatized the victim.
The case highlights the emotional toll on victims of sexual assault and the long-term impact of delayed justice, especially when evidence is lost and time passes.
The victim’s public advocacy, including her appearance in an AP story in 2021, played a critical role in prompting prosecution and public awareness.

namedEntities.name: Ian Cleary
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A man who sexually assaulted Shannon Keeler in 2013 at Gettysburg College and later sent a Facebook message saying, 'So I raped you,' as part of a 12-step program. He was extradited from France and sentenced to two to four years in prison in 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The central offender in a high-profile case that illustrates the challenges of prosecuting campus sexual assault, especially when the perpetrator evades justice for over a decade.

namedEntities.name: Shannon Keeler
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The victim of a sexual assault that occurred at Gettysburg College in 2013. She pursued legal action for over a decade, eventually leading to prosecution after public advocacy.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Her persistence in seeking justice over 12 years exemplifies the emotional and systemic challenges victims face in campus sexual assault cases.

namedEntities.name: Gettysburg College
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A college in Pennsylvania where the sexual assault occurred in 2013. The location is central to the case's context and institutional accountability.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It represents the setting of the crime and a key institution where campus sexual assault policies and enforcement are under scrutiny.

namedEntities.name: Senior Judge Kevin Hess
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The judge who presided over the sentencing of Ian Cleary in 2025, taking into account Cleary’s remorse, mental health, and guilty plea.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His decision to impose a sentence below state guidelines reflects a nuanced approach to justice that considers both culpability and remorse.

namedEntities.name: Andrea Levy
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Shannon Keeler’s lawyer who criticized the sentencing as being too lenient, despite expressing relief that the case was finally resolved.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She represents the legal advocacy side and highlights concerns about justice being compromised due to leniency and systemic flaws.

namedEntities.name: Metz, France
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A city in France where Ian Cleary was detained on a vagrancy charge in April 2024, which led to his eventual extradition to the U.S.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It shows the cross-border challenges in tracking and prosecuting sexual assault offenders who move internationally.

namedEntities.name: Tesla
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A company where Ian Cleary worked after completing his education in Silicon Valley.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It illustrates Cleary’s life trajectory post-assault, showing how he integrated into a high-profile tech industry environment before being prosecuted.

namedEntities.name: Associated Press (AP)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A news outlet where Shannon Keeler shared her experience in 2021, contributing to the public awareness and eventual indictment of Ian Cleary.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The article demonstrates how media coverage can catalyze legal action in cases where victims have long been silenced or ignored.

namedEntities.name: Adams County District Attorney Brian Sinnett
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The prosecutor who expressed doubt about Cleary’s ability to evade authorities but could not prove he was on the run.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His role shows the challenges prosecutors face in investigating and pursuing cases involving campus sexual assault, especially when the suspect is out of jurisdiction.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man named Ian Cleary, who sexually assaulted a woman at Gettysburg College in 2013, was sentenced to two to four years in prison in 2025 after being extradited from France, where he had been detained on a vagrancy charge. The case, long delayed due to prosecutors’ reluctance to pursue campus sexual assault cases and the loss of evidence, gained momentum after the victim, Shannon Keeler, publicly shared her experience in 2021. Cleary, who sent a Facebook message saying 'So I raped you' in 2019, pleaded guilty and expressed remorse, citing mental health struggles. Despite a sentence below state guidelines, Keeler and her legal team criticized the leniency, emphasizing the emotional toll of 12 years of trauma and systemic failure. The case underscores broader issues of justice, evidence destruction, and the need for systemic reform in how campus sexual assault cases are handled.
title: Man Sentenced for 2013 Campus Sexual Assault After 12-Year Legal Battle
